title.narrative: Mechanism 14022 - APHIAplus Imarisha

description.narrative: APHIAplus Northern Arid Lands is a five-year project funded by USAID to be implemented between June 2012 and June 2017 in eight counties, Turkana, Samburu, Isiolo, Marsabit, Mandera, Wajir, Tana River and Garissa. The project is designed to support integrated service delivery and address social determinants of health by working with existing structures at the county, facility and community levels and building their capacity as necessary to ensure efficiency and effectiveness. The project will work to ensure access to and continuation of services in an area prone to drought, famine, insecurity and other disasters for populations that are nomadic and largely hard to reach. It will build the capacity of partners throughout the life of the project, and continuously transfer more responsibility to manage resources and project activities. APHIAplus builds on the lessons learned during APHIA II, expands successful approaches to high-need districts, and provides more support for interventions addressing the social and economic barriers to healthy lives. Expenditure analysis and programmatic data were used to determine the costs for this program. The program will develop a yearly project monitoring plan that will be reviewed quarterly to maintain good oversight of the program.

Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
APHIAplus Northern Arid Lands is a five-year project funded by USAID to be implemented between June 2012 and June 2017 in eight counties, Turkana, Samburu, Isiolo, Marsabit, Mandera, Wajir, Tana River and Garissa. The project is designed to support integrated service delivery and address social determinants of health by working with existing structures at the county, facility and community levels Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

organisation.narrative: Office of the Global AIDS Coordinator

mailing-address.narrative: 1800 G Street, N.W., Suite 10300, Washington, DC 20006

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.

title.narrative: This area of the State Department website contains the standard terms and conditions documents incorporated by reference into all standard grants, cooperative agreements, fixed amount awards, award to individuals, and property awards to U.S. and foreign recipients that are not Foreign Public Entities.
